paragraphs.text:
%md
# Setup

msg.data:
Setup

Important: This exercise depends on ***Insert previous exercise title here (with link?)*** . If you did not complete that exercise, run the course catch-up script and advance to the current exercise:

$ $DEVSH/scripts/catchup.sh

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Lab

msg.data: Lab

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Compare the Execution Plans of Persisted and Unpersisted Queries

msg.data: Compare the Execution Plans of Persisted and Unpersisted Queries

paragraphs.title: 1 - Join accounts with their associated devices
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a DataFrame that joins account data for all accounts with their associated devices. To save time and effort, some stub code has been provided for you.

msg.data: ??? Add this code here to run ???

paragraphs.text:
%spark2
// Stub: query setup
val accountsDF = spark.read.table("telco.accounts")
val accountDeviceDF = spark.read.option("header","true").option("inferSchema","true").csv("/user/zeppelin/accountdevice")
val accountsDevsDF =  accountsDF.join(accountDeviceDF,$"account_id"=== $"acct_num")

paragraphs.title: 2 - Display info from the new DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md

The query code you pasted above defines a new DataFrame called `accountsDevsDF`, which joins account data and device data. Try executing a query starting with the accountsDevsDF DataFrame that displays the account number, first name, last name and device ID for each row.

%spark2
accountsDevsDF.
select("acct_num","first_name","last_name","device_id").
show(5)

paragraphs.title: 3 - Note the complexity of the query you just executed
paragraphs.text:
%md
In your browser, go to the **SQL** tab of your application's Spark UI, and view the execution visualization of the query you just executed. Take note of the complexity so that you can compare it to later executions when using persistence. 

Remember that queries are listed in the **SQL** tab in the order they were executed, starting with the most recent. The descriptions of multiple executions of the same action will not distinguish one query from another, so make sure you choose the correct one for the query you are looking at.

paragraphs.title: 4 - Persist accountsDevsDF
paragraphs.text:
%md
In your Spark shell, persist the `accountsDevsDF` DataFrame using the default storage level.

%spark2
accountsDevsDF.persist

paragraphs.title: 5 - Repeat the final steps of the query you executed above
paragraphs.text:
%spark2
accountsDevsDF.
select("acct_num","first_name","last_name","device_id").
show(5)

paragraphs.title: 6 - Compare the execution diagram of this query with the one executed before
paragraphs.text:
%md
In the browser, reload the Spark UI **SQL** tab, and view the execution diagram for the query just executed. Notice that it has far fewer steps. Instead of reading, filtering, and joining the data from the two sources, it reads the persisted data from memory. If you hover your mouse over the memory scan step, you will see that the only operation it performs on the data in memory is the last step of the query: the unpersisted select transformation. Compare the diagram for this query with the first one you executed above, before persisting.

paragraphs.title: 7 - Analyze the two execution diagrams
paragraphs.text:
%md
The first time you execute a query on a persisted DataFrame, Dataset, or RDD, Spark has to execute the full query in order to materialize the data that gets saved in memory or on disk. Compare the difference between the first and second queries after executing `persist` by re-executing the query one final time. Then use the Spark UI to compare both queries executed after the `persist` operation, and consider these questions.

- Do the execution diagrams differ? Why or why not?
- Did one query take longer than the other? If so, which one, and why?

msg.data:
• Do the execution diagrams differ? Why or why not?
  • Did one query take longer than the other? If so, which one, and why?

paragraphs.text:
%md
### View Storage for Persisted DataFrames

msg.data: View Storage for Persisted DataFrames

paragraphs.title: 8 - Review the properties of the RDD
paragraphs.text:
%md
View the **Storage** tab in the Spark UI to see currently persisted data. The list shows the RDD identified by the execution plan for the query that generated the data. Consider these questions.

- What is the storage level of the RDD?
- How many partitions of the RDD were persisted and how much space do those partitions take up in memory and on disk?
- Note that only a small percentage of the data is cached. Why is that? How could you cache more of the data?
- Click the RDD name to view the storage details. Which executors are storing data for this RDD?

msg.data:
• What is the storage level of the RDD?
  • How many partitions of the RDD were persisted and how much space do those
    partitions take up in memory and on disk?
  • Note that only a small percentage of the data is cached. Why is that? How could
    you cache more of the data?
  • Click the RDD name to view the storage details. Which executors are storing data
    for this RDD?

paragraphs.title: 9 - Execute the query using the write action
paragraphs.text:
%md
Execute the same query as above using the write action instead of show.

msg.data: Execute the same query as above using the write action instead of show.

paragraphs.text:
%spark2
accountsDevsDF.write.mode("overwrite").
save("/user/zeppelin/accounts_devices")

paragraphs.title: 10 - Analyze the storage used with the new version of the query
paragraphs.text:
%md
Reload the Spark UI **Storage** tab.

- What percentage of the data is cached? Why? How does this compare to the last
time you persisted the data?
- How much memory is the data taking up? How much disk space?

msg.data:
Reload the Spark UI Storage tab.

  • What percentage of the data is cached? Why? How does this compare to the last
    time you persisted the data?
  • How much memory is the data taking up? How much disk space?

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Change the Storage Level for the Persisted DataFrame

msg.data: Change the Storage Level for the Persisted DataFrame

paragraphs.title: 11 - Unpersist the accountsDevsDF DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
accountsDevsDF.unpersist()

paragraphs.title: 12 - Verify that the cache has been removed
paragraphs.text:
%md
View the Spark UI **Storage** to verify that the cache for `accountsDevsDF` has been removed.

paragraphs.title: 13 - Persist the same DataFrame again
paragraphs.text:
%md
Repersist the same DataFrame, setting the storage level to save the data files on disk, replicated twice.

%spark2
import org.apache.spark.storage.StorageLevel

accountsDevsDF.persist(StorageLevel.DISK_ONLY_2)

paragraphs.title: 14 - Re-execute the previous query
paragraphs.text: %spark2

paragraphs.title: 15 - Analyze how the data is stored
paragraphs.text:
%md
Reload the **Storage** tab to confirm that the storage level for the RDD is set correctly.
Also consider these questions:

- How much memory is the data taking up? How much disk space?
- Which executors are storing the RDD's data files?
- How many partitions are stored? Are they replicated? Where?

msg.data:
Reload the Storage tab to confirm that the storage level for the RDD is set correctly.
Also consider these questions:

  • How much memory is the data taking up? How much disk space?
  • Which executors are storing the RDD's data files?
  • How many partitions are stored? Are they replicated? Where?

%md

paragraphs.text:
%md
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials](http://hortonworks.com/tutorials/#tuts-developers) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC)](https://community.hortonworks.com/spaces/85/data-science.html?type=question) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/spark-overview/content/analyzing_data_with_apache_spark.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/zeppelin-overview/content/overview.html) - official Zeppelin documentation.
